content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Easy but challenging enough, in particular for reverse.

It looks very nice for clash of code!
I just find it a bit unusual to have the number of lines (n) in the same line as the decoding parameters (f, c, x). In particular in reverse mode I think it might be very puzzling. I would suggest to put it on a separate first line.
Following dogonthesun's comment, maybe you could also add a sentence in the "goal" section to explain that John encrypted the quote by adding characters.

❌ Rejected the contribution.
Comment: The interesting task but the mysterious statement. I can't really get what you mean under "Count c of consecutive chars to read, Next x char position to read" until I haven't reviewed test cases. Probably, it would be better to explain a bit the algorithm of encoding.

It also uses unicode characters which may have lack of support in different programming languages. The task isn't solvable in pure C where strings are represented as null-terminated arrays.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Slightly hard but good clash!

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Easy enough to be finished in 5 minutes by most people, tricky enough to reject your code once or twice if you're too careless,  clear and understandable tests, solution is immediate and improvable: 
Very suited for speed, reverse and short. 
Thank you!

OK wyenat : I agree +1 with your comment :-) !
Thank you.

OK Pancake1 : all is based on the "Substring" function in C# ...
-> It's very useful in some texts decryption ;-) !
Thanks for your approval.

Hi dogonthesun !
I'm sorry for Unicode unexpected chars ...
-> I've checked all, and correct them !
=> Now, all chars may be OK. -> Can you check too, please ?

I've updated the First line explanations too ...
-> Maybe it would better ?

Hi Benoi !
(look like a neighbor ?)

Thanks for your feedback and suggestions ...
-> I've updated to Goal part to clarify (i hope) the encryption method,
-> and i updated all the tests to get the number of lines (n) alone on the first input line.

=> How better is it now for you, please ?

Ah oui en effet ! Bonjour voisin !

=> Great !
